div.p: 4. VI:15— Cloudy— Snow.

Heard Little— Psalm 51.11. “Cast me not away from thy presence; and take not thy holy Spirit from me.”— The text was far more affecting than the discourse— The weather was bad, and the Snow deterred me from going out afternoon or evening. I wrote a short Letter to my Son George, and another to my brother. Read a multitude of Papers about Silas Dinsmoor once a deputy Surveyor, and George Davis one of the Surveyor’s General— Also about the removal of a Land-Office from Delaware to Tiffin in the State of Ohio. A distracting question of State, upon which perhaps depends the political standing and election of two or three members of Congress— And I signed the Message to both Houses of Congress upon the Surveys made by authority of the Legislature and Governor of Georgia, upon Lands secured by Treaty to the Creek Indians— This is the most momentous Message I have ever sent to Congress, and it is to go in to morrow— Well may I say Cast me not away from thy presence and take not thy holy Spirit from me— Measures like this demand deep meditation, before determining upon them; but when once fixed, the less they are thought of perhaps the better— The Solitude of this day has somewhat reconciled me to the rapid succession and endless variety of subjects which absorb and distract my time almost every day during the Session of Congress— Visitors, Petitioners and Solicitors; heads of Departments, Calls of Congress and Despatches engross every moment of almost every hour, and at least keep off brooding Cares— These are vain and idle; but in Solitude they crawl upon one like a nest of Spiders— And now let me wait in patience and self-possession the issue of these Events and say there’s a Divinity that shapes our ends

lg.l: Rough hew them, how we will.

Graham— George— I gave him J. Wilson’s charges against him upon which he made some explanatory remarks, and took them with him to give further written explanations— Of S. Dinsmoor’s Accounts, he said they might be examined and checked by the present Deputy Surveyor Turner; and then settled— Southard said Houston asked him on Saturday Night, to deliver his answer to General Jackson’s Letter to him—open—and not to send it through the Post-Office— I suggested to Mr Southard the propriety of his answering the Letter by a cool denial of the imputations upon General Jackson, which imported a departure on his part from public duty; without indicating any sensibility to the violation of the confidence of social intercourse, or to the tale-bearing misrepresentations which had called forth the General’s Letter—and without noticing the insidious allegation of the General, imputing to the Government of the United States, the Sentiments expressed on a casual topic of conversation at a dinner table— I observed if Jackson should be content with the denial of all imputation upon his character, the controversy would cease there with Southard’s answer; but if Jackson intended to make a public quarrel of it, these outrages of decency and delicacy on his part, might be discussed more usefully to the public, than with him— John and Charles dined at Mr Obregon’s.
6. V:15. symbols 1 symbols 20 symbols— Fog.

Dr Watkins spoke of P S. Markley, the charges against him and his defence— He says he has paid M’Lean his money, and has the check at Norristown— That the 10 dollars he is said to have paid M’Lane in 1824. was a gift— I told Dinsmoor he must settle his accounts with Turner, the deputy Surveyor— I returned to Mr M’Lean the Postmaster General the papers relating to the appointment of a Postmaster at Hagerstown— Kennedy is a minor— Hall a defaulter— I recommended to him the appointment of Stull— Mason brought the Treaty from Mexico; unratified— Gave his opinion of the Mexicans— Mixture of blood— They will maintain their Independence and Republicanism— Army of nearly 40000 men— Connell from Philadelphia—claims on Denmark— Trial of Harris vs Lewis, now before the Court at Philadelphia— Judge Huston— G. M. Dallas— C. J. Ingersoll and H. Binney. Counsel for Harris— Joseph Ingersoll and Chauncey for Lewis— Coles late Governor of Illinois—a visit— Captain Claxton—deaf— Took J. Sergeant to Vera-Cruz— Captain Dumas— I told him, I could not allow his claim— His papers mislaid— Letcher called to recommend John Speed Smith for the appointment of Secretary to the Territory of Florida— Rush had been at the Meeting of the Commissioners of the sinking fund— Macon attended as President of the Senate— Markley’s answer yesterday; unsatisfactory: to call upon him again to-morrow. J. C. Spencer’s Letter and the Hydrometer— A further experiment to be made at New-York— Catlett here this Evening— Said he had the record of Rachel Roberts’s divorce, for adultery—certified by Thomas Allen, Clerk of Mercer County-Court Kentucky. By an Act of the Legislature of Virginia in 1790. Hening’s Statutes at Large. Vol: 13. Peyton Short, and Andrew Jackson— Webster came from H.R—just adjourned about 8. P.M— Saunders’s Resolution— Woollen Bill— Georgia Surveyors on Creek Indian Lands— No new Legislation necessary— Letcher’s wish— Coll. Wool—

Mr Bailey’s reply was to gross misrepresentation and falsehood in a newspaper reiterated after he had declared it false— The language used was charged with passionate epithets, base, infamous, villainous which I advised him to omit— Mr Bell apologized, for having voted against judge Scott of Arkansas, on the ground of his having killed Selden in a duel— He spoke also of the politics of New-Hampshire, somewhat doubtingly— Governor Barbour mentioned the conflicting recommendations between the Indian Senators for an Indian Subagency— Mr Clay mentioned the Instructions to be given to Mr Gallatin, and Gallatin’s wish to come home— Said it would be impossible for him to prepare the Instructions concerning the Eastern Boundary— Had thoughts of employing E— Livingston— I mentioned Holmes— J. Connell, dined and spent part of the Evening with me.

list.item: Message to S.U.S. Army brevet nominations.

div.p: 8. V symbols 3 symbols 1 symbols 20 symbols— Fog— Cloudy

This man brought several half volumes of Stereotype Editions of Whiston’s Josephus, and Rollin’s Antient History; and a Bible all in Quarto—with indifferent Plates, which he thought fine— Knox’s Elegant Extracts, being in Octavo;— I promised to take . . . copy of them as published in numbers— Eadus came again upon his claim of indemnity for property destroyed on the Niagara frontier during the late war— The accounting Officers cannot allow his claim and he appeals to me; and from me to the opinion of the Attorney General— And he intreated me to solicit Mr Wirt in his behalf— The blind man was a beggar— Watkins had a Letter from Binns with extracts from G. M. Dallas’s abuse of me in his speech on the trial of Harris vs Lewis. Watkins also recommended Coll. T. Randall to be Secretary for the territory of Florida, to which he is going— Knight and Angel came as the Committee of enrolled Bills with five Acts of Congress which I signed. Mr Graham took the papers he had left with me, in part prepared in answer to a call from the Senate— Southard read me two Letters from Blackford and Gray, two persons who were present at the dinner table conversation at Welford’s, which has been reported and misrepresented to General Jackson— Governor Barbour brought me a copy of an Act of the Legislature of the State of Alabama, extending the Jurisdiction of the State over the Indian Territory within the limits of the State— White came to urge the appointment of a Secretary for the Territory of Florida— Mr Wirt came in the Evening to ask Instructions concerning a cause in the Supreme Court—about Madrazo— Bowen’s Negroes— The Governor of Georgia has given them up to Bowen— I sent to Congress a Message, with Governor Troup’s Letter to me, and the enclosures about his Surveyors on Indian Lands— Had some conversation with Everett concerning it.
9. V:30. symbols 1 symbols 20 symbols— Sun cloud veiled

Mrs Noland is an aged woman who came to solicit relief in distress— Mr Chambers came to speak of the nomination of J. R Poinsett, for the mission to Tacubaya— Spoke of its confirmation by the Senate as doubtful— I told him the reasons which had induced me to nominate him; and that I should acquiesce in any decision of the Senate upon it. He mentioned an assertion of Tazewell, that it appeared from the documents, communicated to the Senate, that we could not attend the transferred Congress, unless with a new invitation— Said he was surprized to find on examining the documents that the assertion was totally unfounded; but that on conversing with a neighbour of Tazewell’s he learnt this was a practice for which he was notorious. Conway came to recommend some person, for a judge in Arkansas; in the event of Scott’s being finally rejected by the Senate. But he did not name him— Southard and Barbour were here together— Southard gave me to read the answer he has prepared to General Jackson’s Letter— It is as I had recommended, cool, and cautiously avoids every offensive expression— He will send it, sealed. Governor Barbour took the two plats of the lines between Georgia and Alabama, as drawn by the Commissioners of Georgia— Mr Clay spoke of a circular to several of the foreign Ministers here, complaining of the conduct of their Servants, on the Drawing room Evenings— He spoke also of the appointment of a Minister to the Republic of Colombia, and recommended General Harrison— Company to dine— The Judges and Bar of the Supreme Court— I spoke to Judge Johnson of this controversy with Georgia, which I told him would first be tried by him— He said he would laugh them out of it— The Chief Justice said Judge Peters had written to enquire if C. J. Ingersoll’s 600 indictments could not be consolidated— The Georgia Messages were this day referred by H.R.U.S. to a select Committee of 7. The day was spent in debate upon it.
10. V:30. symbols 1 symbols 15 symbols. Sun rose 6:31 = 6:48

Mr Shedd came to solicit a contribution for a Presbyterian Church, for the benefit of Seamen to be built at New-Orleans— I sent for General Brown and had some conversation with him respecting a Memorial which I have received from the Artillery Officers, at Fortress Monroe, remonstrating against the alleged right of Coll. Bissell to be appointed to the Office of Colonel of the second Regiment of Artillery— A Bill to produce that effect has been introduced into both Houses of Congress—into the Senate with a Report from T. H. Benton, drawn up with great art, and some inaccuracy to present Bissell as having a right to the appointment; and to arrears of pay from 1821 when he was dismissed from the Service— Brown said that the remonstrance from the Officers at Fortress Monroe had been sent to me at his suggestion: and that he would take care that the facts should be known to members of the House— I asked General Brown, if he had sent an order to Coll. Armistead to come back here after he had been discharged by the Calhoun Committee— He said he had; at Mr Calhoun’s request, and without due reflection as it would have been more regular for him to have referred Mr Calhoun, to the Committee for an order. Mr Calhoun’s object, apparently was to have Armistead and Swift arrive here at the same time, to confront them together— They did arrive here at the same time; Swift was examined, but they were not confronted— Swift called on General Brown once; and said he would call again but did not— He spoke not a word to him about his examination— Mills is weaker and more exhausted than when last here— His re-election to the Senate is yet doubtful. He spoke with regret of his inability to take an active part in the debates of the Senate; and it is a great misfortune to me— Mr Lawrence came with Mr Krepps, whom he recommended for employment to make Surveys— He is a member of the Pennsylvania Legislature— W. H. Allen, came to tell me he was going very soon to Florida— Wherefore I conclude he has procured bondsmen; which Mr White doubted whether he would be able to do— He also urgently recommended his father for the appointment of Marshal for the middle District of Florida—chiefly on the recommendation of his distress— The woollen bill, passed the House of Representatives this Evening at 6. by a majority of 11. after a protracted and desperate struggle.
Heard Little— 2. Corinthians 4.3–4.

“3. But if our gospel be hid, it is hid to them that are lost. 4 In whom the god of this world hath blinded the minds of them which believe not, lest the light of the glorious gospel of Christ who is the image of God, should shine unto them.”
Hagner— Peter—visit.
P.M. Heard Mr Post, at Mr Baker’s— John 3.16.
“For God so loved the world, that he gave his only begotten Son, that whosoever believeth in him should not perish but have everlasting life.”
Evening— Heard Little. Matthew 23.24.
“Blind guides, which strain at a gnat, and swallow a camel.”

Mr Little’s morning discourse was desultory, and not very impressive— His Evening Lecture, gave an account of the introduction into the Christian Church of the Doctrine of the Trinity; which he ascribed principally to Justin-Martyr, about the middle, and Tertullian toward the close of the second century— He contended it was unknown in the first century, and gave an extract from the dialogue between Justin, and Trypho the Jew, to shew the difficulty with which the doctrine had to contend at its first promulgation— He gave also some account of the controversy between Alexander Bishop of and Arius Presbyter of the same church, and of the manner in which the Trinity was made to prevail at the Council of Nice by a minority of 318 bishops, out of more than a thousand— He made light of the miracle by which Constantine affected to have been converted to the Christian faith and ascribed that event altogether to worldly motives— Mr Post’s Sermon in the afternoon was a mere common-place of Calvinism— There was a flight of Snow this morning; and a keen clear Northwester afternoon and Evening—
12— VI— symbols 45 symbols Sun rose 6:27:30 = 6:46.

Mr Baker came to ask me to speak in his favour to Mr Graham the Commissioner of the General Land-Office. The number of Clerks employed in it is to be reduced by six, among whom Mr Baker is not ambitious of being included— He spoke of the poverty of his Church, from which he receives only 600 dollars a year for Salary, which is now half a year in arrear— Mr Converse is to be the publisher of Noah Webster’s great English Dictionary and came to ask for my subscription— I told him I would take a copy of the Book— There are to be two large Quarto Volumes— Subscription 20 dollars— The cost of the publication will be 20000 dollars, and with charges for collecting subscriptions will require 1200 subscribers to pay the prime cost— But Converse says he will begin the publication if he can obtain 800— Eadus came again for a line from me to the Attorney General about his claim— I told him I had spoken of it to that Officer— Mr Brent came to ask for the last Despatches from Mr Gallatin; which I had been reading, and which were somewhat voluminous— Mr Bailey had published in the National Intelligencer of this morning, his reply to the repeated falsehoods of the New-Hampshire Patriot— Most of the epithets which I had objected to were stricken out; but there was still temper visible in the publication more than I should have thought prudent— Connell read me part of two Letters from Philadelphia, concerning the trial of the suit of L. Harris against W— Lewis— Mr Wirt came to introduce Mr Gamble, and Niles, Mr Egerton— White came to urge the appointment of Mr Downing as Secretary of the Territory of Florida; and told me that W. H. Allen had obtained a Bondsman, responsible enough as to the amount of his property; but a great Speculator in the Florida Lands— His name is Chare— Governor Barbour brought me another Letter from the Governor of Georgia—of 26. January, argumentative against fact— Mr Rush had sent me the answers of several Collectors, to a circular, enquiring of the prospects of revenue from importations during the present year— We spoke also of the investment of the monies payable for Slave indemnities, to yield an interest to the claimants till paid— Mr Taylor the Speaker, and Mr Everett were here in the Evening— Everett is Chairman of the Committee of the House, on the Creek Indian and Georgia Survey Messages: and the complaining Resolutions of the Legislature of Georgia, have also been referred to them— He was enquiring about facts and documents for which I referred him to the War Department—
13— V:15— symbols 15 symbols— Cloudy

Mr Lowrie brought me Resolutions of the Senate advising and consenting to the appointments of Joel R. Poinsett, as joint Minister with John Sergeant to the Assembly of American Nations at Tacubaya, transferred from Panama—of John Boyle, as Judge of the District Court in Kentucky and of Sidney Breese as U—S— Attorney for the District of Illinois— These nominations have been for sometime suspended— General Harrison came to enquire if I had decided upon the claim of Alexander Scott junr. I told him I considered the claim as not only unwarranted by Law but directly contrary to Laws and sustained by no Precedent; although there had been one case of an allowance of pay to a suspended officer for a short time, but no reason assigned for the allowance— He spoke also with some uneasiness and dissatisfaction of a Resolution, moved by J. T. Austin in the Senate of Massachusetts, looking to a claim of Public Lands for the Benefit of the Old States of the Union— I told him I thought it would not meet with much support— Mr Brush came to take leave—returning to Ohio— And said something of Mr Clay’s being run for Vice-President at the next Election; which he thought might be necessary to secure the States of Illinois and Missouri— Mr Wilson came to take leave, returning to Florida. William Lee, with a Letter from W— Duane— who writes of the Creek Indian and Georgia Messages—favourably— A Mr Black of Alexandria, brought a petition from Sandford Anderson, to be discharged from Prison— It was signed by a recommendation from the Mayor of Alexandria, and others; and on being referred to the District Attorney Swann came back with his recommendation also— Captain BallardG. W. Slacum, Consul at Buenos-Ayres, with his brother and T. L. Thruston and Doctor Holcombe with a young Jerseyman named Maxwell came successively as visitors— I had received from Mr White the Delegate from Florida, charges against W. H. Allen, with a request that I would remove him as Receiver of Public Monies in Florida— He was informed of them, and he came to defend himself— I gave him the charges, to take a copy of them—he denied some of them; and explained others— He will make his defence in writing, and I recommended one of the charges specially to his attention— Mr Southard told me that General Houston had declined forwarding his answer to General Jackson’s Letter, unless delivered to him open— He thought, and I concurred with him that his course was to forward the answer to General Jackson directly, by another hand; apprizing him that General Houston declined forwarding it unless open— The Calhoun Committee reported this day—two.
14. V:30. symbols 1 symbols 15 symbols Sun rose 6:24:45 = 6:44

Visit from Mr Baldwin of Pittsburg; heretofore a member of Congress— Also from General Van Rensselaer, with Mr Kane the Senator from Illinois and his father who is an inhabitant of Albany. Mr Bradley came to solicit a Clerkship— Genl Brown told me he had conversed with Mr Vance, Chairman of the Military Committee H.R.U.S. That he did not approve the Bill reported by the Committee for the appointment of a Coll. to the second Regiment of Artillery— It seems to require the appointment of Bissell, with rank and pay for seven years that he has been out of the army— Brown said the Bill was drawn by Mr Drayton; who did not wish the appointment of Bissell, but of Mitchell, the member of the present Congress from Maryland; who had left the army in disgust, because he had been over-slaughed— I said if Bissell should be appointed with back rank and pay, he might ere long be commander in chief of the army: for if I should decide the question of rank between Gaines and Scott, whichever I should prefer I expected the other would resign— He said he thought not—perhaps they might fight: The Secretary of War, took the two Letters from the Governor of Georgia, to be answered: and spoke of the two Reports from the Calhoun Committee especially that of Dr Floyd the Chairman, which is a laborious effort to sustain Major Vandeventer; still chief Clerk in the War Department; and one of the Sharers in the Rip-Rap Contract— Governor Barbour also asked me whether Mr Van Buren might not be appointed Minister to England, upon Mr Gallatin’s return next Summer, I did not encourage this idea— Mr Clay spoke of the Instructions to be given to Mr Gallatin— I agreed that he should be authorised to renew the Convention of Octr 1818. without alteration for ten years—preferring that term, to the one proposed by the British Government of 20 or 15 years— I would leave the North-western boundary in Statu quo; rather than accept anything proposed by the British, or concede anything to them— A Statement must be made to present to the Umpire, in relation to the North-eastern boundary— The prospects of our relations with G. Britain are dark— Mrs Adams was very ill last night, and kept her bed this day till the evening, when she attended the Drawing-Room— It was crowded more than usual—
15. VI:30. symbols 1 symbols 15 symbols Cold Rain—

Mr Everett came, and shewed me a draft of three Resolutions which he has drawn as Chairman of the Committee of the House, to whom my two Georgia Messages have been referred— They declare the Indian Springs Treaty to be null and void: that of last Winter to be in full force, and the third proposes an appropriation to purchase the remnant of the Creek Lands in Georgia. He asked if the last of these would be necessary— I told him it would not. We could negotiate, and in the event of success ask for the appropriation afterwards— But I desired him to invite the attention of the Committee to the accusitorial Resolutions of the Legislature of Georgia; particularly the first, upon which I had begun writing some remarks— I also referred him to the documents shewing the reasons for my refusal to remove John Crowell as the Agent, and to try General Gaines by a Court-Martial— I requested him particularly to call for all the Documents relating to the subject, on file at the War Department— And he said he would see me again, before making the Report— Mr Bacon came with Mr Hawley as the Agent of Bishop Chase of Ohio, for contribution to the establishment of Kenyon College in that State— I had received a printed and a written Letter from the Bishop, soliciting for the same object— Captain Dumas came for his Letter of appeal to me, from the decision of the Secretary of War upon his claim and I returned it to him— Connell came and took leave returning to-morrow to Philadelphia— He told me there was great difference between the reputation of H. Binney; and that of C. J. Ingersoll— Mr Rush whom I had consulted, to ascertain, if a payment of principal of the debt to the amount of two Millions might not be made on the first of April, concludes after enquiry that it could not, without much inconvenience— I agreed that conformably to the recommendation of the Grand Jury at Philadelphia, the District Attorney C. J. Ingersoll should be instructed to discontinue the Indictments against the two Mackies and in the cases of Edward Thompson’s Teas; but we are yet at a loss ho to compel him to try all the offenses charged, by one tenth or less of the Bills that he has caused to be presented— I was writing all the Evening.
16. V:45. symbols 1 symbols 5 symbols Sun-rose 6:21 = 6:41.

Mr Graham came to say that the Register and Receiver of the Land-Office in East Florida, upon a representation from the Governor and Council of the Territory, had upon their own authority advertised a large addition of the Sales of Lands, ordered to be made next May— He seemed disposed to sanction their advertisement in part—of the propriety of which I had much doubt— He said that this Wilson who has presented twelve charges against him to me, and 24 to the House of Representatives, had been an Officer in the army; three times Court-martialed, and twice sentenced to be cashiered in the space of 18 Months. Mr Kankey Commercial Agent at Barbadoes came, just arrived in a British vessel owned in that Island— He sailed from that Island, about the last of December, and chartered two other vessels besides the one in which he came, to come and take cargoes here for the West-Indies— The interdiction upon the Vessels of the United States there took effect on the first of December. It operates severely upon the interest of the Planters in that, and all the other British Islands— He says the exports must be almost universally be shipped for England; the planters being much indebted to the merchants there— And that although our vessels after the 5th. of January 1826 might have cleared out with cargoes, for any part of the world except Great-Britain, yet not one of them did so— Mr Bell of the Senate called to make some enquiries concerning two Articles of the Treaty with Mexico, now before them— That containing the stipulation that neutral property shall be prize of War, taken in enemy’s vessels— And that by which Spanish subjects are excluded from the advantages secured to Citizens of the United States in Mexico. Governor Barbour, brought me a complaint against J. Crowell, the agent to the Creeks, signed by the Little Prince, and others of his party, and forwarded by John Ridge the Cherokee— The paper though written in English was not witnessed nor did it appear by whom written— I thought Crowell should be informed of it, and asked Mr Barbour if Brearley might be appointed in Crowell’s place— He said there were bad complaints against Brearley, though he was favoured by Cobb. He had some thought of T. M. Randolph, but feared his excentricties. Mr Southard read to me a Letter from General Houston, refusing to forward Southard’s Answer to General Jackson, unless delivered to him unsealed— The Diplomatic Corps dined with me— Salazar-Colombia, at my right and Obregon-Mexico at my left hand— Mareuil France, was indisposed and did not come.
17. V:15 symbols 1. symbols 15 symbols Sun rose 6:19:30 = 6:40.

Mr Graham brought me the Resolution of the Governor and Council of Florida, and the Letter of the Register and Receiver, announcing that without authority from the Commissioner of the Land-Office they had advertised a large Sale of Lands— I desired him to counter order the Sale, and in strong terms to disapprove their advertisement without Authority— He also brought Letters from G Davis the Surveyor in Louisiana, and from the Deputy Surveyor Mr Turner, which he said explained why S. Dinsmoor had been so unwilling to settle his Accounts with them— A great proportion of the Records for which he has charged, it appears was never made—at least is not returned with his papers— W. H. Allen came with his defence against the charges of Joseph M. White; and an Affidavit of his bondsman Chaire’s that he had no interest in Land-claims to be decided by Allen— I advised Allen, to go immediately to Florida; to enter vigorously upon the discharge of the duties of his Office, and to avoid very cautiously all impropriety of conduct which he promised me he would— Dr Huntt and Mr C. Munroe came as a Committee from the Subscribers to the Ball on the 22d. to invite my attendance and I accepted the invitation— Mr Frye called to speak of the Land rights of the Heirs of Joshua Johnson in Georgia— He said the rights of the Heirs of Wallace and Muir were now all concentrated in one person, and it might be necessary to do the same with the rights of the Heirs of Mr Johnson; to which I declared my readiness to assent. Bennett came to apply for an appointment of Consul at Rio Grande in Brazil— I referred him to the Department of State— Mr Rush who had yesterday sent an excuse for not dining here, now gave me the cause—which was a sudden Call from S. Smith, Chairman of the Committee of Finance of the Senate, for information relating to the Loan-Bill now before the Senate— He read me Smith’s Letter and his Answer— Mr Clay spoke of a Letter from Rodney at the Havanna, stating an intention of the Spanish Commodore La Borde, to attack Commodore Porter at Key-West, where he has taken refuge— Mr Clay was for taking vigorous measures to vindicate our territorial rights— I agreed to a Cabinet Meeting on Monday at 1. to discuss the Subject— Mr Southard brought a list of nominations for promotion in the Navy— He spoke again of his Correspondence with Generals Houston and Jackson— He has forwarded his answer to the latter— Mr Bailey was here an hour of the Evening. Spoke of an intention to remain here through the Summer.
Heard Little— Proverbs 6–6.7.8

6. Go to the ant, thou sluggard; consider her ways, and be wise. 7. Which having no guide, overseer, or ruler, 8 Provideth her meat in the summer, and gathereth her food in the harvest. a very impressive discourse upon Industry— Full of moral Instruction, and sound principle; addressed as much to the females of his auditory as to the men, and urging with great cogency the necessity that every one should work, as well as eat— There were some satirical remarks interspersed with his argument—he said that even St. Paul, would not allow widows to be provided for till they were 60 years old; nor then without a great many ifs— 1. Tim: 5.10.

Afternoon I went to St. John’s, and instead of Mr Hawley, unexpectedly heard a black man, from Mark 2:14—“Follow me.” He read the Evening prayer for Sexagesime Sunday, and read a Sermon, rambling in argument, not below mediocrity in composition; and quite upon a level with the average of Sunday Discourses from white preachers— There was in his manner both ease and solemnity— The Galleries were stocked with numbers of black and coloured men and women, to whom the preacher specially addressed much of his Sermon— He made no allusion whatever to their colour; but appealed to motives for following Jesus Christ applicable eminently to the poor— He appeared to be in the scale of intellectual being, a step above Prince Sanders.

In the Evening I attended again at Mr Little’s, and heard him, from Acts 17.11—“and searched the Scriptures daily, whether those things were so.” He digressed from the historical narrative of the rise and progress of Christianity to discuss the question whether the doctrine of the Trinity had any warrant in Scripture— He chiefly considered Matthew 28.19. and the first Chapter of John’s Gospel— But neither this nor any other argument that I ever heard can satisfy my judgment, that the doctrine of the Divinity of Christ is notcountenanced by the new Testament— As little . . . I say that it is clearly revealed— It is often obscurely intimated sometimes directly, and sometimes indirectly asserted—but left on the whole in a debateable State; never to be either demonstrated or refuted, till another Revelation shall clear it up.

Harrison came to recommend General Jessup for the appointment of Minister to the Republic of Colombia— Congress are depriving the Staff-Officers, at the head of the Bureaus, of their double rations: Harrison said Jesup could not afford to lose them and must resign— Mr Rice came to introduce the Revd Mr Lewis of Virginia. Governour Barbour came to tell me that he should this day remove Major Vandeventer from the Office of Chief Clerk of the Department of War; and consulted me as to the best mode— Whether simply to dismiss him, or to assign to him the reasons for his dismission— I thought the first course the best, and he said his judgment had been the same. He did accordingly dismiss him and appointed C. J. Nourse in his place— Herrick offered himself as a Candidate for the Office of Postmaster at Portland, Maine; which is to be shortly vacant— S. C. Allen of Massachusetts, introduced Mr Willard a young man from his District on Connecticut River— I sent Mr Ironside to speak of the printed Proclamations of Indian Treaties— I sent a Message with copies of three of them to Congress. Leland came to ask for a place— Roberdeau and Long as visitors— Cabinet Meeting to consider what shall be done, if Commodore La Borde, should actually take Commodore Porter at Key-West— Certainly make heavy remonstrance—complaint and demand of Satisfaction to the Spanish Government— Whether to propose to Congress immediate retaliation—very doubtful— Orders to be given to our own Naval Officers to protect by force if necessary, the neutrality of our own territory— But Porter himself, should not be permitted to make our territory, his Lair, for sallying forth upon his enemy— There was some discussion, upon the necessity of Acts of Congress, for carrying into effect the Treaties with Colombia, Guatimala and Denmark. Mr Clay deeming it necessary— Mr Tomlinson, Chairman of the Committee of Commerce had applied to him to know if an Act of Congress was desired on the Subject. It was concluded to leave it for Consideration till the next Session— Elgar came to enquire if I had authorised Persico to work several hours a day, upon the model of a Statue at the top of the Washington Baltimore Monument— I said I had referred Persico to him, and thought he could not be indulged, to withdraw his time from the Pediment of the Capitol— Which he now says he will not be able to finish this Season. Silsbee was here in the Evening. Spoke of the next Vice-Presidency; which he says W. H. Harrison looks to very earnestly— Levington was the black Preacher of yesterday and came for contribution to an African Church in Baltimore—

I had sent to ask Coll. Dwight to dine with me yesterday; but the House sat in the Evening, and he sent an excuse— He came this morning— Ingham in a debate in the House upon the Appropriation Bill, last Wednesday, made an insidious attack upon me, for some allowances in my Accounts misstated, in the Document (N. 79. 18. Congress. 2— Session 21— February 1825.) printed with the Report of the Committee of which he was Chairman, upon Mr Monroe’s Accounts and Claims— The contingent accounts, allowed, of several other of our Ministers abroad, were printed with that Report of Ingham’s, and mine among the rest—in the Document from the Register’s Office, there was an erroneous charge of 1000 dollars, stated . . . allowed to me, but which had really been an allowance to W— S— Smith— Ingham has kept it two years in reserve, and now pounced upon me with it, upon some item for an outfit to Poinsett in the Appropriation Bill of the present year— I explained the real circumstances of these allowances in my Accounts. . . . Dwight, as a Member of the Committee of Ways and Means, and asked him to explain them to the Committee and to the House: which he promised to do. . . . had drawn up some remarks, on Ingham’s speech, which I read to Dwight, but which not being quite finished I promised to send him this Evening or tomorrow— Morning— Mr Love came to ask for all the Letters of Recommendation in his favour, heretofore sent to me; which he said he wished to present to Mr Clay to obtain a Clerkship in his Department— O’Brien came to enquire if I had received Dr. Ayer—Surveyor at Eastport’s defence; but I had not— He spoke also . . . the probable vacancy of the Collector’s Office at Castine, by the Death, or resignation of Hook the present Collector, whose brother and Deputy he wished might . . .t be appointed in his place— I told him I should wait to hear from him— Mr Tutt and Scott, of Virginia came to solicit appointments— General Brown shewed me a Letter from Judge Spencer of Albany, severely commenting upon the conduct of Governor Clinton of New-York, whom he considers as having broken himself down, and who he says will be abandoned by his own party— Brown . . .ks the same— The General spoke to me of the double Rations of the Staff officers here, now cut-off, and said they had been allowed by Mr Jefferson. Moore of Alabama recommended Alexander Adair as Attorney for the middle district of Florida—and asked for a Survey of the Muscle Shoals— Mr Rush brought explanatory papers of P. S. Markley, which he thought satisfactory, and Governor Barbour the proceedings of a Court Martial upon Lieutt. Wilkins sentenced to be cashiered.
21. VI. Capitol Rotunda— Gevelot. Cloudy

Mr Love called again, and I returned him his Letters of recommendation. Mr White came to urge the appointment of Commissioners to make a Treaty with the Florida Indians and to remove them west of the Mississippi. He mentioned his having withdrawn his charges against W. H. Allen, and pressed for the appointment of a Secretary to the Territory of Florida, and a Marshal for the middle district— Mr Van Buren came to introduce Ludlow who is from New-York— Cramer as a visitor; and Willis from Charleston S.C. with a Letter from his father, and one from Charles B. Cochrane my old Schoolmate of Passy who wants a place— Chase— Richards— Hebb, and Jeremy Robinson all came to solicit appointments, and each one had an affecting narrative of his wants to detail, and numerous Letters of Recommendation to offer— Mr Daniel Brent brought a list of vacant Consulates, appointments to which are to be made, and a large bundle of Letters, containing applications and Recommendations for them— Mr Rush had sundry papers relating to business; among which a Letter to the Collector of New-York requesting him to cause experiments to be made with the Hydrometer of Tucker and Dwelle, comparatively with that of Dicas— He had also the papers furnished by P. S. Markley in his defense, which he thinks on the whole satisfactory; and he had a Letter from General Hiester at Harrisburg renewing the recommendation of Markley for the appointment of Naval Officer at Philadelphia— Mr Dorsey came with Mr Hebb to recommend him, and remained some time after he withdrew— He spoke of the personal attacks upon me, made in the House of Representatives, and I explained to him as I had done to Coll. Dwight, the facts misrepresented by Ingham— He mentioned also the Resolution, debated already three or four weeks; for enquiring of Mr Clay, his Reasons for changing certain Printers of the Laws in Newspapers upon which Dorsey himself made a Speech of two or three days.
22. VI:45. symbols Cloudy

Mr Knight and Mr Forward of the Committee of enrolled Bills, brought Seven Acts for my Signature which were accordingly signed, and notified to the respective Houses— Garnsey came with a Mr Munford, who had a gunlock of his own invention, for firing without flint or pan—with a single kernel of composed powder—the experiment of which he tried twice before me— Messrs.Dorr and M’Lean were visitors. Mr Bailey had received from Dr. Waterhouse, an extract of my Letter to him of 24. October 1813. relating to the People of the Western Country—he wished to furnish copies of it to some of the Western Members of Congress; to which I had no objection— While he was here the Rifle Company came in to the Yard, and paid me a firing Salute of three rounds— Mr Clay having called in upon business was soon followed by the three other heads of Departments— The Secretary of War, had received a Letter from Satterlee Clarke, directly charging Coll Towson, the paymaster General, with having sworn falsely before the investigating Calhoun Committee; demanding his arrest, and trial by Court-Martial upon this Charge, and reserving to himself the right of bringing other charges against him before the Court— After discussion it was agreed, that the answer to Clarke should refer him to the civil Tribunals of the District; by the Grand-Jury: the offence if committed being cognizable by the Circuit Court—always to be preferred, when resort can be had to it, to the martial-law— The Company of Washington Guards paid me a marching Salute. At eight in the Evening, the Marshal Ringgold came, and I went with him to the Washington Birth-Night Ball, at Gadsby’s Hotel now first opened, in the Pennsylvania-Avenue— Mrs Adams and Mary Hellen, were both too unwell to go— I came home before Supper, and soon after ten— The Marshal came with me, but my Sons staid till 3. of the Morning— My Son Charles brought me a Letter from E. Everett, enclosing one from Mr P. C. Brooks, relating to a proposal of engagement, by Charles, between him and Mr Brooks’s daughter.
23. V:15. symbols 1 symbols 15 symbols. Cloudy— Chronometer ran down

I answered Mr P. C. Brooks’s Letter— Mr Lowrie brought me Resolutions of the Senate, confirming the Brevet nominations in the Army—and one for a Report of information, at the next Session of Congress— I asked him for two Messages of President Washington to the Senate concerning Indian Treaties; which he promised me— The Revd. Messrs.Rowan and M’Carty came for a contribution for a new engraving of the Declaration of Independence, certified by Charles Carroll of Carrollton, the only survivor—on the 2d. of August 1826. Fifty years complete from the day of the signature— Mr Rowan also gave me a copy of an Address which he delivered at New-York, on the Death of Adams and Jefferson— Buchanan came to introduce Mr Jacobs from Lancaster— Clark and Buckner, recommended at Mr Weddeburne, for Surveyor of the Port of Alexandria, in the place of Captain Dangerfield who died suddenly yesterday— Watkins came with Taylor to recommend him for the same place— Mr Vowell came to recommend a Mr Brown, and Brown to recommend himself, and to shew objections to the appointment of others— George Taylor urgently recommended a friend of his for the appointment at Alexandria— White the Delegate from Florida, instant in Season, and out of Season to get the Indians removed out of that Territory, and for the Appointments there. Mr Chambers the Senator from Maryland introduced a Mr Scott of Baltimore. John Williams, returned from his . . . as Charge d’Affaires at Guatemala. Conversation with him concerning the Affairs of that Country. Carr came to recommend a friend— The Revd.Dr Glendy of Baltimore called for a visit— Has a Son a Midshipman in the Navy— Dean and Lewis reside at Fredericktown, and came from curiosity alone to see the President— Mr Clay spoke of his draught of Instructions to Mr Gallatin, and his private Letter, respecting Gallatin’s great anxiety to come home— I told him I believed I should nominate B. T. Watts as Chargé d’Affaires to Colombia, and postpone the appointment of a Minister till the next Session of Congress at least— Mr Clay would nominate a Chargé d’Affaires, and a Minister Plenipotentiary at the same time— I received this Evening a Note from E. Everett— Appropriation for the House reduced from $25000 to $6000.
24. V:15. symbols Heavy Rain— Thunder

Silsbee came and introduced a Mr Alsop of New-York not long since from Peru—and I think the principal author of all the charges against Commodore Stewart, upon his last command in the Pacific— Robbins and Pearce came to recommend a man by the name of Cranston, as Navy Agent, in Rhode-Island— I referred them to the Secretary of the Navy— Mr Fowle of Alexandria, came with Mr Wattles; fervently recommending him for the appointment of Surveyor at that Port— Aaron Day is a man deaf, and dumb, who has invented a boat of some extraordinary properties, for which he came to ask a Patent; a Subscription, and a contribution— Davis was his companion and interpreter— Mr Southard came merely to introduce Mr Scott of New-Jersey— They met here Mr Rush, who remembered Scott as a fellow Collegian at Princeton— Mr Rush had a large number of applications for the appointment of Surveyor at Alexandria, and a Petition from a man named Tucker; for a remission of forfeiture of his vessel, for transporting Slaves contrary to the Law of 1808. which I signed— Rush had also a Letter, recommending P. S. Markley for the appointment of Naval-Officer, at Philadelphia, from Markley’s successor to the next Congress Sterigere— I sent to both Houses of Congress a Message with the annual Report from the Director of the Mint; and Mr Rush, returned to his Office to despatch that from the Treasury— I sent also to the Senate, a Message with the Treaty of Conveyance from the Seneca Indians to Troup, Ogden, and Rogers of New-York— Mr J. Johnson one of the Members from that City, came with six of his friends, who he said were stirred up to come here, by the woolen Bill; the Colonial trade Bill, and the Bill for reducing the duties on Salt; Wines and Teas— Coll. R. Jones the Adjutant General had the Resolutions of the Senate advising to the promotions, and Brevets in the Army— I gave him also the proceedings of the Court-Martial upon Lieutenant Wilkins, with the Sentence, Cashiering him for drunkenness, approved by me— Coll. Dwight passed an hour with me this Evening, and said he had not yet had an opportunity in the House, of giving the explanations, I had furnished him with upon the items in my old Accounts upon which Ingham commented—
25. V.30. Cloudy—
Heard Little— Romans 13.10. “Love worketh no ill to his neighbour—therefore love is the fulfilling of the law.”— A Sermon upon Benevolence—

Visits after Morning Church— Johnston and Webster spoke of the Colonial trade Bill, now under discussion in the Senate— The first Section of the Bill reported by the Committee of Commerce of that Body, has been stricken out, and there are four or five different projects before them, with six days of the Session left for both Houses to Act upon the Bill— One of the Projects is to give the President a power to interdict the British shipping from the Colonies by Proclamation— Mr Webster asked if that would not answer as well as a contingent interdict by Law. I said no— Because the measure taken by the Executive alone, would not have the weight of an Act of Congress— If however they meant to shift the responsible burden upon the Executive I would take it upon me— It seems extremely doubtful, whether any Act of Congress upon the subject will pass at this Session— Webster said he would call upon me again this Evening.

In the afternoon, I heard a Stranger at Mr Baker’s, from 1. Timothy 4–8— “But godliness is profitable unto all things”— The preacher quoted Milton, Shakespear, Pope, Young and Cowper, to prove the position of his text.

Mr Webster did not call in the Evening— I wrote to my Son George and was engaged till near Midnight, in tracing through the second Volume of U.S. Laws, the Journals of the old Congress, and the Speeches of President Washington, the History of our Relations with the Indian Tribes since the Revolution—and the origin of the Army—with its progressive increase— This examination like many others leads me deeper and deeper in research till I am compelled to stay my enquiries for want of Time to pursue them— In the controversy with Georgia, the powers of the General Government, and those of the Government of Georgia, are in conflict, and it is indispensable to know the whole History of our Indian relations of Peace and War, to understand the ground upon which we stand— It was debateable ground far more under the Confederation than now; but Georgia and some other States are disposed to revert to the State Claims under the Confederation—

Mr O’Brien came to say that he had received Letters from Eastport, from respectable quarters which led him to believe that Samuel Ayer had been traduced, and to wish that he might be reappointed to the Surveyor’s Office at that Port— Mr Rush also sent me from the Treasury, Ayer’s defence of himself against the charges imputed to him— Mr Webster called for two objects; one of which was to recommend John Speed Smith of Kentucky for some appointment abroad or at home— The other to advise against the appointment of a man, named Hook at Castine; brother of the present Collector, who wishes to resign; on condition that his brother shall be appointed in his place— Genl. Van Rensselaer introduced Mr Low, a young man from New-York— Mr Estill, two constituents from his District, Mr Smith and Mr Trigg—and Mr Dorsey. Mr Johnson a member of the Senate of Maryland— Scott came to apply for the appointment of Superintendent of the Cumberland Road— Knapp for that of a Clerk in the Department of State; under a Law, now on its passage through Congress: and John Allen the Mathematical Professor and Clergyman of Baltimore for that of Marshal in the Middle District of Florida— He brought a Florida bird, a Nonpareil, in a Cage, as a present from his Son. W. H. Allen to Mrs Adams— Thornton came to solicit the appointment of Surveyor at Alexandria for his uncle William Wedderburn— Mrs Stutt a Shopkeeper at Alexandria, came with three small children, whom I declined seeing; to obtain the remission of a fine imposed on her by the Mayor of Alexandria, of 12 dollars and charges for selling Spirituous liquors without license— I referred her to the District Attorney. Governor Barbour proposed to employ Joseph M. White the Delegate from Florida, to ascertain if the Florida Indians can be prevailed upon to sell the remnant of their Lands and remove beyond the Mississippi, to which I agreed— He had a Letter from Cobb enquiring why I had not denounced an Act of the Legislature of Alabama, extending their Jurisdiction over the Indians within their Territory— I desired him to answer because the bearing of the lawful power of the Union, is upon the Acts of Individuals, and not upon the Legislation of the States— Mr Clay spoke much of the Postmaster General, whom he wished to have appointed Minister to the Republic of Colombia—
27. V:15 symbols 1 symbols 20 symbols Drizzling Mist.

Mrs Offord came to solicit Charity— Lowrie brought two Resolutions of the Senate— One, advising a conditional ratification of the Treaty with Mexico— The other rejecting the renomination of Andrew Scott as a Judge in the Territory of Arkansas—because he killed his associate judge, Selden, in a duel— Mr Greene is Marshal of the State of Maine; and spoke of the state of politics there as precarious— He also mentioned the prospect of a vacancy in the Office of Collector at Castine, by the death of the Collector Josiah Hook, who is disposed to resign, on condition that his brother, now deputy Collector, shall be appointed in his place— He also recommended a petition of discharge for 3 persons, in prison upon penalties which they are not able to pay— Edwards has recently returned from China; after having suffered Shipwreck, at the Sandwich Islands— He makes heavy complaints against Lieutenant Percival, Commander of the U.S. Schooner Dolphin, which was sent by Commodore Hull to those Islands— Mr Brent came to enquire for a draught of a despatch to J. R. Poinsett, which I gave him— I sent also to the Department of State the Mexican Treaty returned from the Senate. Mr Wood, of the House from New-York, came and introduced the Townsend’s father and Son, the latter of whom is going upon his travels in Europe— Wood gave him advice how to spend his time profitably, by a complete course of Statistics and Political Economy— The other Major Townsend, is a son of Dr Townsend of Boston— He came from Roxbury and brought me a packet from Mr Boylston, with Prints of the prophets Joel and Zechariah from Michael Angelo— Mr Rush had a claim of a man, appointed under a Resolution of Congress to take depositions— A demand of near 600 dollars which I thought heavy, but which was sanctioned by Precedent— Scott urged the appointment of T. P. Eskridge, as judge in Arkansas, in the place of his brother, and Allen, for District Attorney in Missouri in place of Bates— I had company to dine Messrs.Alsop, Breckenridge, Bulfinch, Clay, Crowninshield, Dorsey, Dwight, Edwards, Estill, Johnson, Low, Ludlow, Preston, Silsbee, Smith, Trigg, Van Buren, Van Rensselaer, Webster, John and Lewis Williams— Coolidge and Cramer sent excuses— E. Everett was here in the Evening, and read to me his draught of a Report on the Georgia and Creek Messages— We had other Conversation also.
28— V:15. symbols Cloudy.

Mr Graham called to shew me a Letter to him from the Surveyor General Edward Tiffin, declaring in warm language his Indignation at the Charges brought by Wilson against Graham, before the House of Representatives— Upon which charges a Committee of the House reported yesterday, entirely in Graham’s favour— Barber came to introduce Mr Mitchell a Senator in the Legislature of Connecticut, and Mr Southard, the Revd. Mr Stewart a Missionary to the Sandwich Islands— Mr Bell, a Senator from New-Hampshire came to take leave, prior to the close of the Session of Congress— He spoke somewhat doubtfully of the State— Trimble, came to recommend Thomas Marshall of Kentucky, for a Judge in Arkansaw— Mr Clay introduced Crittenden, the Secretary of that Territory— Miner came to take leave— Bates and Brown, are Woollen Manufacturers at Steubenville Ohio, who are going home, disappointed by the failure of the Bill increasing the duties on woollens— Wilson introduced the Revd. John Herbst, who solicited a contribution, for a Lutheran German Theological Seminary at Gettysburg, Pennsylvania— Captain of the Navy came to pay a visit, just from New-York— Chase came to take leave— Bateman, to introduce a Doctor Hampton— General Brown told me that Mr Calhoun, had sent him a Message, by Doctor Lovell, the Surgeon General, to say that he Calhoun was not satisfied with the Testimony given by Brown, before the . . .-Calhoun Committee— Brown took it much to heart—and the more because he says he has been twice alone with Mr Calhoun since he gave that testimony, and Calhoun did not speak of it to him— William Lee spoke of electioneering pamphlets circulated about here, in the Country— Governor Barbour brought me a new list of promotions in the Army, to be nominated to the Senate— He had left undecided the question whether Coll. Jones adjutant General, and only a Captain of the line should be included in the list or not; but left with me an argument by Jones in his own favour, which on perusal I thought conclusive— Governor Barbour told me he was worn out with business— Titus was a young man from Winchester, Virginia, who came to see me, merely to indulge his curiosity— Answered this evening a Letter received yesterday from E. H. Mills—
